choices.A: Have business, user and supplier stakeholder representation
choices.D: Have an effective strategy to manage communication flows to and from stakeholders
choices.C: Ensure appropriate governance by defining responsibilities for directing, managing and delivering the project and clearly defining accountability at all levels
choices.B: Never be reviewed as members should stay with the team for the duration

questions.question_text:
Which of the following is False?
A Successful project management team should.

discussion.content: B is CORRECT (it is the only answer which is false). Answer A is not false, according to 7.1. (beginning of page 60) successful project management team should have all three stakeholders representation :)

Therefore, all three stakeholder interests need to be represented effectively in the project management team;
two out of three is not enough
A is correct, see 7.1

C should be correct 
Page 91, Section 8.4.4
Unless some background information are missing. Who said the review activities are completed?

comments.content: I was confusing B with C, my mistake
The answer C clearly states that quality review activities are completed though.
The question mentions 'While preparing for the quality review'

discussion.content: Therefore, the answer is B. Yes, because the quality reviewers should update the quality register as quality review activities are completed. The quality reviewers are responsible for updating the quality register as quality review activities are completed

Selected Answer: C
Refer to 8.4.4 Preparing For review 
Submit a question list to the chair and presenter ahead of the review (reviewers).

comments.content: Correcting my previous answer. Correct answer is option D - senior supplier can not be made reviewer as the supplier is responsible for developing the product and thus the quality review won't work.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The Senior Supplier is the (ultimate) responsible for products to be developed in the project, so he cannot act as a reviewer of these products because it generates a conflict of interests.
The question is about activity not role.....ie B
No, because the senior supplier should not be identified as a reviewer as part of the quality review technique.

choices.B: Yes, because the quality reviewers should update the quality register as quality review activities are completed.
choices.C: No, because possible errors that are found when preparing for a quality review should be documented on a question list.
choices.A: Yes, because each team manager should update the quality register as quality review activities are completed.
choices.D: No, because the senior supplier should not be identified as a reviewer as part of the quality review technique.

questions.question_text:
At the end of stage 2, an external consultant responsible for developing the 'e-learning course', was appointed to the project board as a senior supplier. The stage
3 plan identifies the consultant as a reviewer of the 'e-learning course'. When preparing for a quality review of the 'e-learning course', the consultant found 15 possible errors. The consultant then documented these possible errors in the quality register.
Is this an appropriate activity when preparing for a quality review, and why?

choices.B: Agree and prioritize the acceptance criteria during the initiation stage, because they can be amended through change control, if needed.
choices.A: Agree and prioritize the acceptance criteria during the initiation stage, because these criteria will be used to determine if the project can be closed.
choices.D: Set the quality tolerances for the acceptance criteria in the product descriptions, because quality tolerances define the acceptable range.
choices.C: Set the quality tolerances for the acceptance criteria in the product descriptions, because this would allow for additional changes in legislation.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Please note that acceptance criteria are in the Project Product Description not in the Products Descriptions (there we found quality criteria) so C and D are false. B is the only choice that addresses the capability of project management to cope with a changing environment, i.e. by exploiting the change management practice.

questions.question_text:
ABC has experience of delivering training projects that respond to new legislation. Previous projects have had to change the acceptance criteria, due to further updates being made to legislation during the project.
What action should be taken to address this, and why?

choices.C: No, because the risks inherent in the project plan should be assessed, and the plan modified to manage them.
choices.B: Yes, because risk planning should take place in the stage plan before the risks occur, not in the project plan.
choices.A: Yes, because detailed planning of stage 3 should take place after completion of the stage 2 products.
choices.D: No, because the risk actions to manage project-level threats should be recorded in the risk register.

questions.question_text:
During the 'create the project plan' activity as part of the initiation stage, the project manager identifies several threats to the project timescales. These threats relate to stage 3 products. Therefore, the project manager decides to wait until the end of stage 2 to assess the risks to the project plan.
Is this an appropriate application of the plans theme, and why?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Refer 9.3.1.7
After the plan has been produced, it should still be considered a draft until the risks inherent in the plan have been identified and assessed, and the plan possibly modified. 
Though option D is true, but it mentions about risk actions not the identified risk itself.
D. No, because it should be used to prioritize change based on the project's business justification

Selected Answer: D
Refer 9.4.1 
MoSCoW can be used for other types of prioritization, such as prioritizing changes, by adapting the criteria as necessary. 
When MoSCoW is used in this way, the criteria for must have, should have and could have
should always be based on the impact on business justification, in line with PRINCE2's continued business. 
justification principle

Selected Answer: B
Definitely its a 'yes' answer (There are many ways to prioritize a change request and PRINCE2 introduces the MoSCoW technique - p2wiki), and relates to the entire quality, not just the time. Therefore, answer is B.

Selected Answer: D
prioritize requirements according to business justification

Selected Answer: C
I think it is C. MoSCoW technique is a way of prioritizing product requirements so basically setting tolerances on the project scope (what the project has to deliver) supporting managing by exception (in this case scope exceptions).
D is correct Answer

9.4.1 The MoSCoW prioritization technique:
When MoSCoW is used in this way, the criteria for must have, should have and could have should always be based on the impact on business justification, in line with PRINCE2’s continued business justification principle.
yes correct answer is d
correct is d

choices.B: Yes, because it is a prioritization technique that should be used to prioritize a product's quality criteria.
choices.C: No, because it should define scope tolerances, supporting the management by exception principle.
choices.A: Yes, because it should be used to prioritize change based on the estimated impact on time.
choices.D: No, because it should be used to prioritize change based on the project's business justification.

questions.question_text:
A change authority has been appointed for the project. During the development of the 'classroom-based training material', a large number of changes were proposed to the design of the 'e-learning course'. Therefore, the change authority has decided to use the Moscow technique to prioritize changes based on the impact they will have on completing each stage on time.
Is this an appropriate application of the Moscow technique, and why?
